displayPoint: DAK, Counselling conducted on non-pharma measures to relieve nausea and vomiting
action: Conduct counselling on physiological symptoms    and advice on dietary management
annotation: Small and frequent feeding. Avoid triggering factors.Ginger, chamomile, and vitamin B6 recommended for the relief of nausea in early pregnancy, depending on a woman’s preferences and available options. Women should be informed that symptoms of nausea and vomiting usually resolve in the second half of pregnancy.

displayPoint: DAK, Counselling conducted on pharmacological treatments for nausea and vomiting
action: Conduct counselling on physiological symptoms   . Start management OR refer if no improvement
annotation: Pharmacological treatments for nausea and vomiting, such as doxylamine and metoclopramide, should be reserved for those pregnant women experiencing distressing symptoms that are not relieved by non-pharmacological options, under the supervision of a medical doctor due to side-effects of the anti emetics.

displayPoint: DAK, Counselling conducted on diet and lifestyle changes to prevent and relieve heartburn
annotation: Advice on diet and lifestyle  (e.g. small and frequent feeding, avoid spicy and fatty foods, avoid sleeping in supine position immediately after eating, and adding pillows when necessary).

displayPoint: DAK, Counselling conducted on antacid preparations to relieve heartburn
action: Conduct counselling on physiological symptoms  .Start management OR refer if no improvement
annotation: Antacid preparations and other pharmacological treatments can be offered to women with troublesome symptoms that are not relieved by lifestyle modification.

displayPoint: DAK, Counselling on non-pharmacological treatment for the relief of leg cramps
annotation: Non-pharmacological therapies, including muscle stretching, relaxation, heat therapy, dorsiflexion of the foot, and massage can be used for the relief of leg cramps in pregnancy

displayPoint: DAK, Counselling conducted on use of magnesium and calcium to relieve leg cramps
action: Conduct counselling on physiological symptoms  .Start management OR refer if no improvement
annotation: If leg cramps are not relieved with non-pharmacological measures, then give 300–360 mg magnesium per day in two or three divided doses; give calcium 1 g twice daily for two weeks. These medifications might be avilabale in antenatal supplments

displayPoint: DAK, Chronic Hypertension
action: Conduct hypertension Counselling and Refer her for further evaluation and manegment if neccessay.
annotation:
Woman has hypertension – SBP of 140 mmHg or higher and/or DBP of 90 mmHg or higher before 20 weeks of gestational age and no proteinuria.

Counselling:
– Advice to reduce workload and to rest
– Advise on danger signs
– Reassess at the next contact or in 1 week
– If hypertension persists after 1 week or at next contact, refer to hospital or discuss case with the doctor, if available

displayPoint: DAK, seven-day antibiotic regimen for asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB) not provided
action: Provide 7-day antibiotic regimen for asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB)
annotation: A woman is considered to have ASB when she has no urinary symptoms but either positive gram staining or positive urine dipstick test (nitrites or leukocytes). A seven-day antibiotic regimen is recommended for all pregnant women with asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB) to prevent persistent bacteriuria, preterm birth, and low birth weight.

Seven-day antibiotic regimen is recommended for all pregnant women with UTI to prevent preterm birth and low birth weight.

displayPoint: DAK, Counselling conducted on anaemia
annotation:
Anaemia can be diagnosed if Hb level is less than 11 in first or third trimester or Hb level less than 10.5 in second trimester; OR there is no Hb test result recorded, but woman has pallor.

If a woman is diagnosed with anaemia during pregnancy, conduct counselling for managing and treating anaemia. 

Her daily elemental iron should be increased to 120 mg until her haemoglobin (Hb) concentration rises to normal (Hb 110 g/L or higher). Thereafter, she can resume the standard daily antenatal iron dose to prevent recurrence of anaemia.

The equivalent of 120 mg of elemental iron equals 600 mg of ferrous sulfate heptahydrate, 360 mg of ferrous fumarate or 1000 mg of ferrous gluconate.

Please refer to iron sources listed below for additional guidance that can be provided.

displayPoint: DAK, Counselling conducted on anaemia
annotation:
If a woman is not diagnosed for anaemia, iron and folic acid supplementation is still recommended. 

Due to the population's high anaemia prevalence, a daily dose of 60 mg of elemental iron is preferred over a lower dose. A daily dose of 400 micrograms (0.4 mg) folic acid is also recommended.

The equivalent of 60 mg of elemental iron is 300 mg of ferrous sulfate heptahydrate, 180 mg of ferrous fumarate or 500 mg of ferrous gluconate.

Please refer to iron sources listed below for additional guidance that can be provided.

displayPoint: DAK, Counselling conducted on anaemia
annotation:
If a woman is not diagnosed for anaemia, iron and folic acid supplementation is still recommended. 

Daily oral iron and folic acid supplementation with 30–60 mg of elemental iron and 400 micrograms (0.4 mg) of folic acidc to prevent maternal anaemia, puerperal sepsis, low birth weight and preterm birth.

The equivalent of 60 mg of elemental iron is 300 mg of ferrous sulfate hepahydrate, 180 mg of ferrous fumarate or 500 mg of ferrous gluconate.

Please refer to iron sources listed below for additional guidance that can be provided.

displayPoint: DAK, Counselling conducted on anaemia
annotation:
If a woman is not diagnosed for anaemia, iron and folic acid supplementation is still recommended. 

If daily iron is not acceptable due to side-effects, provide intermittent iron and folic acid supplementation instead (120 mg of elemental iron and 2.8 mg of folic acid once weekly).

The equivalent of 120 mg of elemental iron is 600 mg of ferrous sulfate heptahydrate, 360 mg of ferrous fumarate or 1000 mg of ferrous gluconate.

Please refer to iron sources listed below for additional guidance that can be provided.

conditions.key: Population with low dietary calcium intake

displayPoint: DAK, Amount of daily calcium supplements provided
action: Provide calcium supplementation. 1.5 g â‰¤ Amount of calcium supplements provided â‰¤ 2 g
annotation:
In populations with low dietary calcium intake, daily calcium supplementation (1.5–2.0 g oral elemental calcium) is recommended for pregnant women to reduce the risk of pre-eclampsia. 

Dietary counselling of pregnant women should promote adequate calcium intake through locally available, calcium-rich foods such as Injera, Milk and diary product, dried fruit, fish, green leaf vegitables,  almond/nut and figs (Beles)

– Divide the total dose into three doses, preferably taken at meal-time.
– Iron and calcium should preferably be administered several hours apart rather than concomitantly.

conditions.key: DAK, Overt Diabetes mellitus (DM) during pregnancy diagnosis

displayPoint: DAK, Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) risk counselling conducted
action: Conduct counselling on gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) risk
annotation:
The woman is considered at risk for GDM if she has any of the following risk factors: 
– BMI of 30 kg/m2 or more
– Previous GDM
– Previous macrosomia 
– Glycosuria on dipstick testing is ++ or above on one occasion OR + on two or more occasions

Please provide appropriate counselling for GDM risk mitigation, including: 
– Reasserting dietary interventions
– Reasserting physical activity during pregnancy

conditions.key: DAK, Prevalence of HIV in pregnant women in the catchment area

displayPoint: DAK, HIV risk
annotation:
If the woman lives in a setting with a generalized HIV epidemic, or her partner is HIV positive, or she injects drugs, or she is a sex worker, then she is at high risk for HIV – Counselling should be given to provide prevention options

Provide comprehensive HIV prevention options: 
– STI screening and treatment (syndromic and syphilis)
– Condom promotion
– Risk reduction Counselling
– Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) with emphasis on adherence
– Emphasize importance of follow-up ANC contact visits

See "PrEP offering framework" – a suggested prioritization framework for offering PrEP to pregnant and breastfeeding women (below).

annotation: Counsel the woman on the importance of exclusive breastfeeding for the first six months after birth, followed by the introduction of complementary feeding while continuing breastfeeding until the child is two years old

displayPoint: DAK, Counselling on birth preparedness and complications readiness
action: Conduct counselling on birth preparedness and complications readiness
annotation:
Early Ultrasound scan is a must
- Additional contact might be needed
- Early referal preparation

displayPoint: DAK, Counselling on birth preparedness and complications readiness
action: Conduct counselling on birth preparedness and complications readiness
annotation:
Encourage delivery at a health-care facility.
- Additional contact might be needed
- For teenage pregnancy , psychological support counselling is recommended 
- Early referal preparation 

Risk factors necessitating a facility birth:
– Age 17 or under
– Primigravida
– Parity 6 or higher
– Prior caesarian section
– Previous pregnancy complications: heavy bleeding, forceps or vacuum delivery, convulsions, or 3rd or 4th degree tear
– Vaginal bleeding
– Multiple fetuses
– Abnormal fetal presentation
– HIV positive

– Multiple fetuses

– HIV positive
– Wants IUD or tubal ligation following delivery

conditions.key: DAK, Woman discloses or is suspected to be subjected to intimate partner violence

annotation: Cultures and communities have ways of referring to the problem with other words. It is important to use the words that women themselves use.

conditions.key: DAK, Presenting signs and symptoms that trigger suspicion of IPV and clinical inquiry

displayPoint: DAK, Woman discloses or is suspected to be subjected to intimate partner violence
action: Conduct clinical enquiry and provide first-line support and care if IPV confirmed
annotation:
WHO does not recommend universal screening for violence against women attending health care. WHO does encourage health-care providers to raise the topic with women who have injuries or conditions that they suspect may be related to violence.

Never raise the issue of partner violence unless a woman is alone. Even if she is with another woman, that woman could be the mother or sister of an abuser.

If you do ask her about violence, do it in an empathic, non-judgemental manner. Use language that is appropriate and relevant to the culture and community you are working in. Some women may not like the words “violence” and “abuse”

action: Conduct clinical enquiry and provide first-line support and care if IPV confirmed
annotation:
WHO does not recommend universal screening for violence against women attending health care. WHO does encourage health-care providers to raise the topic with women who have injuries or conditions that they suspect may be related to violence.

Never raise the issue of partner violence unless a woman is alone. Even if she is with another woman, that woman could be the mother or sister of an abuser.

If you do ask her about violence, do it in an empathic, non-judgemental manner. Use language that is appropriate and relevant to the culture and community you are working in. Some women may not like the words “violence” and “abuse”

conditions.key: DAK, Has the woman  been subjected to intimate partner violence

action:
Provide first-line support. Four (4) kinds of needs deserve attention:
– Immediate emotional/psychological health needs
– Immediate physical health needs
– Ongoing safety needs
– Ongoing support and mental health needs.
annotation:
Conduct the following 5 tasks: 
– Listen to the woman closely, with empathy, and without judging
– Inquire about needs and concerns: assess and respond to her various needs and concerns – emotional, physical, social and practical (e.g. childcare)
– Validate: show her that you understand and believe her; assure her that she is not to blame
– Enhance saftey: discuss a plan to protect herself from further harm if violence occurs again
– Support her by helping her connect to information, services and social support.

action:
Ask the following questions:  
-Has the physical violence happened more often or gotten worse over the past 6 months? 
- Has he ever used a weapon or threatened you with a weapon? 
- Has he ever tried to strangle you? 
- Do you believe he could kill you? 
- Has he ever beaten you when you were pregnant? 
- Is he violently and constantly jealous of you?
annotation: If woman answers "yes" to at least 3 of the questions, the woman may be at high risk of violence /danger

displayPoint: DAK, Malaria test conducted
annotation: Test all pregnant women living in malaria-endemic areas for malaria parasites and treat accordingly

displayPoint: DAK, Malaria Chemo-prophylaxis provided
action: Do not give IPTp-SP, because woman is taking co-trimoxazole
annotation: IF the woman is currently taking co-trimoxazole, even in a malaria-endemic setting, she should not receive any dose of IPTp-SP. Taking both co-trimoxazole and IPTp-SP together can enhance side-effects, especially haematological side-effects such as anaemia.

conditions.key: DAK, Reason for coming to facility

displayPoint: DAK, HIV test conducted
annotation: An HIV test is required for all pregnant women at the first contact.

displayPoint: DAK, HIV test conducted
annotation: If the woman first HIV test result was negative, retest for HIV  with risk assessment after  the gestational age â‰¥ 30 weeks ( the interval between the two tests should be greater than 3 months)

displayPoint: DAK, HIV test conducted
annotation: A test is not required if the woman is already confirmed HIV positive
Woman's cardiac condition is abnormal and she should be referred urgently to the hospital.Put the woman in semi sitting position and support her with oxygen.

action: Conduct further investigation and, if necessary, refer urgently to a hospital
annotation: Woman's breast exam was abnormal and she should be referred to hospital for further investigation
Woman's abdominal exam result is  abnormal and she should be referred for further evaluation and management

displayPoint: DAK, Counselling conducted on non-pharma measures to relieve nausea and vomiting
action: Conduct counselling on physiological symptoms , look for cause and manage and referral if no improvement
annotation: Non-pharmacological therapies, including muscle stretching, relaxation, heat therapy, dorsiflexion of the foot, and massage can be used for the relief of leg pain in pregnancy. Please assess any possible cause , including thrombosis and varicose veins.

displayPoint: DAK, TB screening conducted
action: Conduct TB screening and if one or more of symptoms present(refer the annotation), link her for further investigation
annotation: TB screening by screening tool ( i.e fever, cough greater than two weeks, night sweating,and weight loss/failure to gain weight) is recommended for all pregnant woman.

conditions.key: DAK, Reason for coming to facility

displayPoint: DAK, Hepatitis B test conducted
annotation: Hepatitis B testing is recommended for all pregnant women.HBsAg laboratory-based immunoassay is the preferred method for testing for Hep B infection in pregnancy; if immunoassay is not available, HBsAg rapid diagnostic test (RDT) is recommended over dried blood spot (DBS) HBsAg testing.
White blood cell count too low!Refer her for further evaluation and management if not explained by the physiological change of the pregnancy

displayPoint: DAK, Counselling conducted on personal hygiene and environmental sanitation
annotation: Handwashing with soap is the most important hygiene action she can take, especially before preparing food and after going to the toilet. A pregnant woman should wash her body regularly with clean water. Moreover, regular cleaning of the teeth with a dental stick or a toothbrush and toothpaste is important for dental hygiene

displayPoint: DAK, Counselling conducted on seeking care when danger signs occur
annotation: Counsel women on how to look out for danger signs and seek care accordingly

conditions.key: DAK, Counselling on ANC contact schedule conducted

annotation: It is recommended that a woman sees a health-care provider 8 times during pregnancy (this can change if the woman has any complications); this schedule shows when the woman should come in to be able to access all the important care and information

conditions.key: DAK, Counsel to immediately go to the hospital if severe danger signs are present

annotation: Counsel women on the importance of immediately going to the hospital if severe danger signs are present

conditions.key: DAK, Counselling on birth preparedness and complications readiness
conditions.value: DAK, Counselling on birth preparedness and complications readiness was not conducted

annotation: Counsel women on preparing for birth and possible complications that may arise

conditions.key: DAK, Counselling on postpartum family planning conducted

annotation: Counsel woman on postpartum family planning methods

displayPoint: DAK, Counselling conducted on malaria prevention
annotation: Counselling on malaria prevention should be conducted during every contact in malaria-endemic settings (where there is moderate to high malaria transmission)

annotation: After the woman has been prescribed calcium supplements, check whether the woman is still continuing to take her calcium supplements

displayPoint: DAK, Counselling conducted on anaemia
annotation: Rule out intestinal infections (and malaria and treat accordingly) , Counsel on compliance with treatment,Reassess at subsequent antenatal visit (4-6 weeks). If anemia persists, refer to hospital. If anemia persists, refer to hospital.Her daily elemental iron should be increased to 120 mg until her haemoglobin (Hb) concentration rises to normal (Hb 110 g/L or higher). Thereafter, she can resume the standard daily antenatal iron dose to prevent recurrence of anaemia. The equivalent of 120 mg of elemental iron equals 600 mg of ferrous sulfate heptahydrate, 360 mg of ferrous fumarate or 1000 mg of ferrous gluconate.

displayPoint: DAK, Counselling conducted on hepatitis B positive
annotation: Provide post-testing counselling and education on measures to reduce the risk of transmitting HBV to the infant, encourage partner testing, and ensure linkage to care of HBsAg positive. Refer to a hospital if necessary.

displayPoint: DAK, Amount of iron prescribed
annotation:
Anaemia can be diagnosed if Hb level is less than 11 in first or third trimester or Hb level less than 10.5 in second trimester; OR there is no Hb test result recorded, but woman has pallor.

If a woman is diagnosed with anaemia during pregnancy, conduct counselling for managing and treating anaemia. 

Her daily elemental iron should be increased to 120 mg until her haemoglobin (Hb) concentration rises to normal (Hb 110 g/L or higher). Thereafter, she can resume the standard daily antenatal iron dose to prevent recurrence of anaemia.

The equivalent of 120 mg of elemental iron equals 600 mg of ferrous sulfate heptahydrate, 360 mg of ferrous fumarate or 1000 mg of ferrous gluconate.

Please refer to iron sources listed below for additional guidance that can be provided.

displayPoint: DAK, Amount of iron prescribed
annotation:
If a woman is not diagnosed for anaemia, iron and folic acid supplementation is still recommended. 

Due to the population's high anaemia prevalence, a daily dose of 60 mg of elemental iron is preferred over a lower dose. A daily dose of 400 micrograms (0.4 mg) folic acid is also recommended.

The equivalent of 60 mg of elemental iron is 300 mg of ferrous sulfate heptahydrate, 180 mg of ferrous fumarate or 500 mg of ferrous gluconate.

Please refer to iron sources listed below for additional guidance that can be provided.

If a woman is not diagnosed for anaemia, iron and folic acid supplementation is still recommended. 

Daily oral iron and folic acid supplementation with 30–60 mg of elemental iron and 400 micrograms (0.4 mg) of folic acidc to prevent maternal anaemia, puerperal sepsis, low birth weight and preterm birth.

The equivalent of 60 mg of elemental iron is 300 mg of ferrous sulfate hepahydrate, 180 mg of ferrous fumarate or 500 mg of ferrous gluconate.

annotation:
If a woman is not diagnosed for anaemia, iron and folic acid supplementation is still recommended. 

If daily iron is not acceptable due to side-effects, provide intermittent iron and folic acid supplementation instead (120 mg of elemental iron and 2.8 mg of folic acid once weekly).

The equivalent of 120 mg of elemental iron is 600 mg of ferrous sulfate heptahydrate, 360 mg of ferrous fumarate or 1000 mg of ferrous gluconate.

Please refer to iron sources listed below for additional guidance that can be provided.

displayPoint: DAK, Counselling conducted on anaemia
annotation: Rule out intestinal infections (and malaria and treat accordingly) , Counsel on compliance with treatment,Reassess at subsequent antenatal visit (4-6 weeks). If anemia persists, refer to hospital. If anemia persists, refer to hospital.Her daily elemental iron should be increased to 120 mg until her haemoglobin (Hb) concentration rises to normal (Hb 110 g/L or higher). Thereafter, she can resume the standard daily antenatal iron dose to prevent recurrence of anaemia. The equivalent of 120 mg of elemental iron equals 600 mg of ferrous sulfate heptahydrate, 360 mg of ferrous fumarate or 1000 mg of ferrous gluconate.

There is acute malnutrition and is an indication for supplementation with ready-to-use foods (e.g., Plumpy’Nut, corn-soy blend [CSB++]) until the measurement is in the normal range

displayPoint: DAK, Counselling conducted on healthy eating and keeping physically active
action: Conduct counselling on increasing daily energy and  protien intake
annotation: Recommended food groups for pregnant women—at least five out of ten: ((1) Grains, white roots and tubers, and plantains (“starchy staples”), (2) Pulses (beans, peas, and lentils), (3)Nuts and seeds, (4)Dairy, (5)Meat, poultry, and fish, (6)Eggs, (7)Dark-green leafy vegetables (8)Other vitamin A-rich fruits and vegetables (9)Other vegetables, (10) Other fruits. Promote physical exercise to prevent maternal overweight and obesity during pregnancy

conditions.key: DAK, Repeat systolic blood pressure after 15 min

action: Provide antihypertensive and anticonvulsant treatment as per protocol, and refer
annotation: Antihypertensives: Hydralazine is the drug of choice for acute therapy. Administer 5 mg IV slowly every 20 minutes until the blood pressure is lowered to a diastolic level of <110 mmHg. The maximum dose is 20 mg within 24 hours. If Hydralazine is unavailable, alternative drugs such as Nifedipine can be used.Anticonvulsants: Administer magnesium sulfate (MgSO₄) as the first-line treatment. If MgSO₄ is unavailable, provide alternative anticonvulsants as per protocol

displayPoint: DAK, seven-day antibiotic regimen for asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB) not provided
action: Provide 7-day antibiotic regimen for asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB)
annotation: A woman is considered to have ASB when she has no urinary symptoms but either positive gram staining or positive urine dipstick test (nitrites or leukocytes). A seven-day antibiotic regimen is recommended for all pregnant women with asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB) to prevent persistent bacteriuria, preterm birth, and low birth weight.

displayPoint: DAK, Syphilis counselling and treatment
annotation: Provide treatment according to the clinical phase of syphilis: – If primary or secondary stage of syphilis, give single dose of benzathine penicillin 2,400,000 IU – If late or unknown stage of syphilis, give one dose of benzathine penicillin 2,400,000 IU weekly for 3 consecutive weeks – Advise on treating partner – Encourage HIV testing and counselling – Reinforce use of condoms – Proceed to further testing with an RPR or VDRL test after 6 months

displayPoint: DAK, Counselling conducted on HIV risk
annotation: If the woman lives in a setting with a generalized HIV epidemic, or her partner is HIV positive, or she injects drugs, or she is a sex worker, then she is at high risk for HIV – counselling should be given to provide prevention options. Provide comprehensive HIV prevention options: STI screening and treatment (syndromic and syphilis), condom promotion, risk reduction counselling, pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) with emphasis on adherence, and emphasize importance of follow-up ANC contact visits.
